Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2 catalysts at different temperatures. Conditions: GHSV=30,000h−1, 1000ppm NO, 1000ppmC3H6, 10vol.% O2, in He as balance. Fig. 2 XRD patterns of the various Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2 catalysts. Fig. 3 FT-IR spectra of pyridine adsorption at different temperatures on various Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2 catalysts (a) Cu/TiO2, (b) Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2, (c) Cu/Ti0.8Ce0.2O2, (d) Cu/Ti0.7Ce0.3O2, (e) Cu/Ti0.5Ce0.5O2, and (f) Cu/CeO2. Fig. 4 The relative quantity of Lewis acid sites with the increasing ratio of Ce/(Ti+Ce). Fig. 5 H2-TPR profiles of the various Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2 catalysts. Fig. 6 XPS spectra of Cu 2p (a) and O 1s (b) of Cu/TiO2, Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 and Cu/CeO2 catalysts. Fig. 7 XPS spectra of Ce 3d of Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 and Cu/CeO2 catalysts. Graphical abstract A series of Cu-supported Ti–Ce mixed oxide catalysts (Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2), with x =0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, 1.0, were evaluated for selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO with C3H6 under lean-burn conditions, and the promotional effect of ceria additive was investigated systematically. Among the tested catalysts, Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 exhibited excellent low-temperature activity, which achieved a maximum N2 yield of 50.3% and NO x conversion of 66.2% at 240°C. The generation of Ti–O–Ce mixed bond raised the quantity of Lewis acid sites and therefore improved the distribution of the copper oxide species on the catalyst surface. The high SCR activity of the Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 was mainly attributed to the abundant Lewis acid sites and the high ratio of adsorbed oxygen on the catalyst surface, which provided more adsorption centers for NO and promoted the NO oxidation in the SCR reaction. Furthermore, the high concentration of Cu2+ was beneficial to NO adsorption. Combined with the in situ FT-IR results, it was suggested that the synergistic effect of ceria and copper promoted the formation and reactivity of nitrates, oxygenated hydrocarbons, and key intermediates isocyanate (–NCO species), and consequently, Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 catalyst exhibited the excellent SCR performance. Keywords Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2 NO reduction Propene SCR Lean burn condition 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides emitted from stationary and mobile sources are one of the major air pollutants in urban areas causing serious damages to the environment and human health as well. In recent years, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x with hydrocarbons has been extensively studied and developed as a potential technology for elimination of NO x , especially the NO x from the transportation sources under oxygen-rich conditions. Although some transition metals, such as V, Fe, Cu, Co, Mn and Mo, have been reported to be active for the SCR process, the traditional catalysts based on these metals do not generally show satisfactory low-temperature performance desirable for practical applications. Cu/ZSM-5 zeolite is a very effective catalyst for NO x reduction, however, its poor thermal and hydrothermal stability limits the practical applications. On the other hand, metal oxide catalysts used as supports or promoters have been widely studied, and the copper oxide-based catalysts have become very attractive recently. Thanks to their excellent low-temperature activity and cost effectiveness, they have been tried as substitutes for noble metal catalysts [1]. It has been reported that CuO/ZrO2 [2], Ti0.9Cu0.1O2−δ [3], copper alumina catalysts [4], and copper-ion exchanged titanium pillared clays (Cu-Ti-PILC) [5] exhibit excellent low-temperature activity in the SCR process, achieving the maximum NO x conversions or N2 yields below 300°C. Due to the sulfur-resistant, high surface area, and non-toxic, TiO2 has been investigated and applied to a great extent as a support in the SCR process [6,7]. The high oxygen storage capacity (OSC), excellent redox properties and strong metal-support interactions behavior of CeO2 resulted in its large scale use as a promoter or active catalyst [8,9]. However, CeO2 exhibits low sintering temperature, which requires the incorporation of other elements into CeO2 composites to form solid solutions as remediation. The formation of solid solutions improves not only the lattice thermal resistance of CeO2, but also the redox and oxygen storage capacity [10,11]. The generation of solid solution by mixing two oxides may form new stable compounds, and thereby leads to different physicochemical properties and catalytic behavior from their individual components [12,13]. Recently, the Ti1−x Ce x O2 solid solution has been considered as a promising support and intensely investigated. As a catalyst or support, Ti1−x Ce x O2 has been used in photodegradation of herbicide 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid [14], low temperature CO oxidation [15], and NO removal [16]. The presence of ceria can significantly increase the SCR activity, and TiO2–CeO2 mixed oxide is found to have high activity and excellent selectivity for N2 formation in NH3-SCR [17,18]. The nature of the support influences the dispersion of active components and thus affects the activity of catalysts. The activity and selectivity of copper oxide catalysts depend to great extent on the texture and the dispersion state of CuO x species which are greatly affected by the surface state of the supports [19]. As a carrier of mixed oxide, CeO2 can increase the dispersion of active components and replace the expensive noble metal catalysts [18]. CuO/CeO2–TiO2 has been reported as an active catalyst for SCR of NO by CO, in which ceria was incorporated into TiO2 by using the conventional impregnation method [20]. However, little attention has been paid to the application of Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2 catalyst in C3H6-SCR of NO, and the analysis about the roles of ceria in the SCR reaction is yet to be fully understood. In this work, the performance of Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2 catalysts with different Ce/(Ce+Ti) atomic ratios was investigated systematically for the C3H6-SCR reaction. The Ti1−x Ce x O2 supports were synthesized using the urea precipitation–gelation method to avoid subsequent inhibition of the deNO x activity, and the easier agglomeration and low dispersion of CeO2 resulting from the conventional impregnation technique. The deNO x capability of various Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2 catalysts, the effect of ceria on the structure and physic-chemical properties, and the relationship between these properties and the deNO x performance were clarified. Furthermore, the role of ceria in the formation and transformation of the adsorbed intermediates on the catalyst surface was analyzed by in situ FT-IR spectroscopy. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ti1−x Ce x O2 supports with different molar compositions were prepared using the urea precipitation–gelation method. The precursors were cerium ammonium nitrate ((NH4)2Ce(NO3)6) and titanium oxysulfate (TiOSO4·2H2O), and the precipitant was urea (CO(NH2)2). The total amount of (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 and TiOSO4·2H2O was 0.0375mol, and the amount of CO(NH2)2 was 35g. The aqueous solution of (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6, TiOSO4·2H2O and CO(NH2)2 was mixed followed by the addition of double-distilled water to bring the total volume of the mixed solution to 500ml. After continuous stirring of mixed solution at 90°C for 8h, the obtained precipitate was washed with double-distilled water and ethanol, dried, and then calcined at 450°C for 6h. The supports were denoted as Ti1−x Ce x O2, where x represents the molar ratio of Ce/(Ce+Ti) in the range of 0–1. The Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2 catalysts were prepared with an impregnation method using an aqueous solution of Cu(CH3COOH)2·H2O, and the Cu loading amount was 5wt%. The samples were dried overnight and calcined at 350°C for 6h. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The specific surface areas of the catalysts were measured by physical adsorption of N2 at −196°C using NOVA 1200 (Quanta Chrome) and calculated according to the BET equation. XRD patterns of the catalysts were recorded using a Rigaku D/Max 2550VB/PC X-ray powder diffractometer (XRD) with a Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.154056nm). H2-TPR analysis was carried out on a Chembet PULSAR TPR/TPD (p/n 02139-1). In a typical experiment, the sample (50mg) was pretreated in a He stream at 200°C for 30min, and the TPR measurement was carried out from 50 to 400°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min in a stream of 10vol.% H2/Ar. The H2 consumption in the effluent was monitored using a TCD detector. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded by a Multilab 2000 electron spectrometer. Binding energies of Cu 2p, O 1s and Ce 3d were calibrated using C 1s (BE=285.6eV) as a standard. The nature of the surface acid sites was studied using FT-IR of adsorbed pyridine on a VERTEX 70-FTIR spectrometer. The sample (∼20mg) was de-gassed at 300°C for 30min under vacuum (1.0×10−3 Pa) to remove the adsorbed moisture, and then cooled to room temperature to collect the spectrum as the background. After the pyridine adsorption at room temperature for 10min at 1.0×10−3 Pa, the temperature-programmed desorption was performed at different temperatures. The sample was heated to a desired temperature at a heating rate of 10°C/min, followed by cooling to room temperature, and then the IR spectra were recorded. 2.3 Catalytic activity tests Catalytic activity measurement for the SCR reaction was carried out in a U-shaped quartz fixed-bed reactor containing 200mg of a catalyst of 20–40mesh. The reactant mixture consisted of 1000ppm NO, 1000ppmC3H6 and 10vol.% O2 with He as the balance. The total gas flow rate was 100ml/min and the GHSV was 30,000h−1 approximately. The concentration of NO, NO2 and CO in the inlet and outlet gases was measured using a chemiluminescen gas analyzer (Testo 350), and the concentration of N2 and C3H6 was measured by a gas chromatograph (TECHCOMP 7890 II) equipped with both TCD and FID detectors. Prior to the SCR test, the catalyst was pretreated in an Ar stream at 250°C for 2h, and the catalyst activity was measured from 150 to 350°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min. 2.4 In situ FT-IR studies The adsorbed species on the catalyst surface in the atmosphere of NO+O2 and NO+C3H6 +O2 were analyzed by in situ FI-IR spectroscopy (VERTEX 70-FTIR, Bruker), equipped with an MCT detector. The spectra were recorded at 4cm−1 resolution and with a scan number of 64, in the range of 4000–400cm−1 wavenumber. The pure sample (∼20mg) was prepared by pressing it into a disk with a diameter of 10mm, and then secured inside the infrared cell which consists of two KBr windows and sample holder for the sample pellet. Prior to each experiment, the sample was pretreated in the stream of He at 250°C for 60min and cooled to the desired temperature. The spectra were collected at different temperatures in the range of 25–350°C. The reaction conditions were 1000ppm NO, 1000ppm C3H6, 10vol.% O2 and He as balance, and the total gas flow rate was 30ml/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic reduction of NO by C3H6 over Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2 Fig. 1 shows the ratios of NO conversion into N2, NO conversion into NO2, NO x conversion and C3H6 conversion as the function of temperature over various Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2 catalysts. The N2 yields over all samples displayed volcano shaped plots, and reached maximum values at about 240°C. As the low N2 yields were obtained at 350°C over various catalysts, the temperature range of catalytic test was selected as 150–350°C. Compared with Cu/TiO2, the maximum N2 yield obtained over Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 sample was enhanced from 40.5% to 50.3%, which suggested that the ceria incorporation promoted the generation of N2. However, the persistent decrease of N2 yield was observed with the further ceria-doping, and the maximum N2 yield was 32.7%, 21.8%, 15.0% and 8.0% when x value was 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, and 1.0, respectively. Interestingly, the ceria introduction greatly enhanced the conversion of NO into NO2 with the increase of temperature as shown in Fig. 1b. The NO2 yield was enhanced with the increase of Ce-doping as follows: 17.0%, 36.1%, 47.8%, 49.5%, 51.6% and 65.3% was obtained at 350°C when x value was 0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, 1.0, respectively. Therefore, the main SCR production was N2 in the temperature range of 150–280°C, while NO was mainly converted into NO2 when the reaction temperature was above 280°C. As NO2 is also a kind of acid gas harmful to the environment, the reduction percentage of NO x (NO+NO2) was performed as presented in Fig. 1c. The maximum NO x conversion over the various catalysts was obtained at 240°C and decreased in the following order: Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 (66.2%)>Cu/Ti0.8Ce0.2O2 (62.2%)>Cu/TiO2 (47.2%)>Cu/Ti0.7Ce0.3O2 (41.6%)>Cu/Ti0.5Ce0.5O2 (38.0%)>Cu/CeO2 (16.3%). Thus, the SCR activity could be improved by the introduction of ceria with appropriate quantity (x =0.1 and 0.2), while further addition induced the generation of more NO2, and NO x reduction suppression as well. As depicted in Fig. 1d, the C3H6 was converted over various catalysts. The highest C3H6 conversion was obtained over Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 catalyst, and the other Cu-supported mixed oxides catalysts exhibited the similar C3H6 oxidation performance but better than that over Cu/TiO2 and Cu/CeO2 samples. The incorporation of ceria into TiO2 lattice increased the amount of oxygen vacancies as well as the mobility of lattice oxygen, hence the enhancement of the oxidation reaction [21,22]. Moreover, the redox ability of Ce3+/Ce4+ was also beneficial to the C3H6 conversion. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 BET and XRD The physical properties of the Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2 catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . The Cu-supported mixed oxide catalysts exhibited higher surface areas and larger pore volumes, and the result was similar with other TiO2 based materials reported previously [23]. The higher surface area and larger pore volume led to efficient mass transfer, hence the enhancement of adsorption capacity of catalysts toward the reactants and intermediates [7]. XRD was used to characterize the changes in structure caused by the ceria addition, and corresponding results are presented in Fig. 2 . It is apparent that the characteristic diffraction peaks of crystalline CuO were not observed, indicating that CuO species were highly dispersed on the surface or existed in amorphous phase. Typical anatase and fluorite phases were observed on Cu/TiO2 and Cu/CeO2 samples, respectively. In the case of Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2, only (101) plane of anatase phase existed with low intensity and no characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to CeO2 was observed. Hence the ceria was well dispersed and existed as an amorphous phase in the bulk of TiO2 and its introduction suppressed the formation of TiO2 crystallite phase. The XRD patterns of other Cu-supported mixed oxide catalysts exhibited only a very broad and weak diffraction peak suggesting the phase transition from anatase to fluorite. From the low intensity of the diffraction peaks over the Ce-containing mixed oxides samples, it was implied that the samples were in poor crystallization and the ceria introduction resulted in the structural distortion and disorder. According to literature [23], the ceria incorporation could inhibit the of individual crystallization process of TiO2 and CeO2, and therefore lead to higher surface area. A poor crystal degree accompanied with the high surface area will promote the dispersion of the active components. Furthermore, the facilitation of ceria with amorphous phase to the SCR reaction has also been reported [16]. 3.2.2 FT-IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine Pyridine-adsorption FT-IR method is widely utilized to investigate the nature of acid sites (Lewis or Brönsted) on the catalyst surface. The FT-IR spectra of pyridine chemisorbed on various Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2 samples are presented in Fig. 3 . The bands around 1445, 1579 and 1600cm−1 are attributed to different vibration modes of pyridine coordinated to the Lewis acid sites, while the band with weak intensity at 1544cm−1 corresponds to the pyridine interacted with Brönsted acid sites. The band around 1490cm−1 is attributed to the complex of Lewis and Brönsted acid [24,25]. It has been reported that the area of the band at 1445cm−1 is proportional to the quantity of the Lewis acid sites [26,27]. Based on this theory, the relative amounts of Lewis acid sites over various catalysts are calculated and results are presented in Fig. 4 , from which the influence of support composition could be observed clearly as well as temperature on the quantity of Lewis acid sites. As shown in Figs. 3 and 4, the amount of the Lewis acid sites was related to the ratio of ceria in the support, and it was decreased gradually with the increasing temperature. The ceria incorporation significantly increased the quantity of the Lewis acid sites on the catalyst surface, and Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 sample possessed the highest amount of Lewis acid sites. Cu/CeO2 possessed the least Lewis acid sites. According to the literature, the quantity of the Lewis acid sites will be raised by the increasing of oxygen vacancy defect sites and the growing of charge balance [28]. Hence, the much more Lewis acid sites over Cu-supported mixed oxide catalysts would not be attributed to the addition of substance with abundant Lewis acid sites, but the changes in crystal structure and electron charge density caused by the generation of Ti–O–Ce mixed bonds. It has been reported that the acid sites may interact with the active components, and therefore inhibit the agglomeration of the active components [29]. Therefore, the abundant acid sites over Cu-supported mixed oxide samples may promote the dispersion of copper species on support surface. Moreover, the increase of the Lewis acid sites would promote the SCR performance by enhancing the activation of C3H6 and the oxidation of NO into NO2 [30–33]. In the previous study by Kikuchi and Yogo [34], oxygen was assumed to be adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites and activated by the electrostatic polarization, then the gas phase NO molecule attacks the activated oxygen to form NO2. Moreover, the Lewis acid sites should be the electron accepters as they are generated by the unsaturated cationic sites, while NO should be the electron donors due to the one-electron bond in the electronic structure. Hence, the NO oxidation into NO2 may occur easily on the Lewis acid sites. The generation of more Lewis acid sites may be a plausible reason for the higher conversion of NO into NO2 over Cu-supported mixed oxide samples. Nevertheless, it should not be the main reason, because the highest NO2 yield was obtained over Cu/CeO2 but the catalyst possessed poor acidity. 3.2.3 H2-TPR Fig. 5 shows the profiles of H2-TPR used to study the influence of the support composition on the reduction processes of the copper oxides. All catalysts exhibited two reduction peaks, indicating the existence of two different types of copper species with different redox behaviors, and the reduction temperatures were significantly lower than that of the bulk CuO, which is reduced nearly to 300°C [35]. The peak denoted as α is attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed copper species strongly interacting with the support. The peak denoted as β is assigned to the larger two- and three-dimensional clusters of copper oxides being weakly associated with the support [15,21,35]. The difference in the reduction temperature and reduction peak area over various catalysts suggested that the Ti/Ce molar ratio changed the nature of supports and therefore affected the interaction between copper oxides and the support. From the quantitative results presented in Table 2 , it was noted that, the total H2 consumption on Ce-containing samples was much higher than that of Cu/TiO2, especially for the well-dispersed copper oxides. It has been widely reported that CeO2 can promote the reduction of finely dispersed CuO surface species by H2 [35]. The value of H2/Cu molar ratio over Cu/TiO2 sample was close to 1, suggesting that CuO was the dominant species, which was confirmed by the XPS result below. However, for the Ce-containing samples, the molar ratio of H2/Cu was much higher than what is necessary for the theoretical complete reduction of copper from the oxidation state +2 to 0, which suggested that the H spillover effect occurred on the support [36]. The excessive amount of hydrogen consumption may be attributed to the reduction of the surface adsorbed oxygen of CeO2 and some part of reducible CeO2 from Ce4+ to Ce3+, as suggested by Zhang et al. [36]. Therefore, it is reasonable to conclude that the difference in H2 consumption was related to the assistance of Cu n+ species in Ce4+/Ce3+ redox. Meanwhile, the substitution of Ti by Ce increased the mobility of lattice oxygen and leads to the easier reduction of ceria. 3.2.4 XPS XPS analysis was performed to confirm the valences of surface copper species, and the Cu 2p spectra of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 6a. The surface of the catalysts was covered by Cu2+, which was characterized by a Cu 2p3/2 binding energy of 933.6eV with a shake-up or satellite peak located at 938.5–946.5eV [36,37]. It has been reported by Dong [37] that the chemisorbed NO occurs on the Cu2+ species, and Iwamoto [38] considered that the Cu2+–O− or Cu2+–O2− species act as the active sites on the Cu-MFI zeolite catalyst. Among the tested samples, the highest intensity of peaks assigned to Cu2+ was observed on Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 sample. Considering its excellent SCR performance, it is considered that the Cu2+ species are able to adsorb and activate NO molecules, and a higher amount of Cu2+ species favors the C3H6-SCR reaction. The O 1s peak was fitted into two sub-bands and the results are shown in Fig. 6b. The peak at 530.4eV corresponds to the lattice oxygen O2− (denoted as OL), and the peak at 532.8eV is attributed to the surface adsorbed oxygen (denoted as OA), such as O2 2− or O− belonging to a defect oxide [22,39]. The ratio of OA/(OA +OL) was calculated by the area ratio of the peak at 532.8eV to the peak at 530.4eV. The relative concentration ratio of OA over the various samples decreased in the order of Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 (15.8%)>Cu/CeO2 (8.0%)>Cu/TiO2 (3.5%). The higher OA ratio of Ce-containing sample may be attributed to the oxygen vacancy generated by the redox cycle of Ce3+/Ce4+. Moreover, the Ti–O–Ce mixed bond may induce the more generation of defects, including charges imbalance and unsaturated chemical bonds, and therefore further elevate the OA ratio over Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 catalysts. Due to its high mobility, surface adsorbed oxygen was more active in the reaction compared with the lattice oxygen, and the high OA ratio should be beneficial to the oxidation of NO into NO2 in the SCR reaction. The Ce 3d core level XPS spectra of Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 and Cu/CeO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 and they were fitted into eight components in accordance with the report by Burroughs et al. [40]. The bands labeled as u (900.9eV), u″ (907.6eV) and u′″ (916.5eV) are arising from Ce4+ 3d3/2, and the bands labeled as v (882.5eV), v″ (889.0eV), and v′″ (898.6eV) are arising from Ce4+ 3d5/2, while u′ (903.9eV) and v′ (885.5eV) are typical final states of Ce3+ [41]. Moreover, the band located at binding energy of 916.5eV has been established as the best characteristic peak for differentiating Ce4+ from Ce3+ [42]. The Ce3+ ratio of Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 (27.3%), calculated by Ce3+/(Ce3+ +Ce4+), was significantly higher than that of Cu/CeO2 (12.8%). The partial substitution of Ce by Ti promoted the reduction from Ce4+ into Ce3+. Generally, the higher Ce3+ ratio indicates the presence of more surface oxygen vacancies generated by the charge compensation [42], which will facilitate the adsorption of oxygen species or activate reactants in SCR reaction. 3.3 In situ FT-IR 3.3.1 Nitrate species formed from NO x adsorption–desorption FT-IR analysis of the adsorbed species on the catalyst surface during the reaction was performed to obtain an insight into the chemical mechanisms involved in the SCR reaction. Fig. 8 shows the in situ FT-IR spectra of NO+O2 co-adsorption at different temperatures over Cu/TiO2, Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 and Cu/CeO2 catalysts. The main adsorbed species on the surface of various catalysts were nitrates. Some characteristic vibrations at 1350–1400cm−1 combined with the bands at 1290 and 1500cm−1 indicate the existence of the monodentate nitrates [43,44]. The band around 1582cm−1 corresponds to the bidentate nitrates, and the vibrations around 1624, 1609 and 1240cm−1 are attributed to the bridging nitrates [22,45]. The bands at 1520 and 1225cm−1 are attributed to the chelate bidentate nitrates, and they are assigned to Ce x+ =(O2)NO− species as they were not detected over Cu/TiO2 sample [46]. In addition, slight formation of nitrite was observed at 1455cm−1 [44]. Decreases in the intensity of the above bands were observed with increasing temperature. The monodentate nitrates were unstable and disappeared completely in the high temperature region. The peaks attributed to the bridging nitrate and bidentate nitrate existed in the whole temperature region, indicating that the adsorption of bridged nitrate and bidentate nitrate on the surfaces of catalysts was more stable than monodentate nitrate during the NO+O2 exposure. Among the tested catalysts, Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 displayed much stronger adsorption toward nitrate species, especially for the bridging nitrate, while the adsorption capacity of Cu/CeO2 was poor, though the intensity of Ce x+ =(O2)NO− species at 1223cm−1 was relatively high. These changes in the intensity of the bands attributed to nitrates with increasing the temperature over the various catalysts can be observed more clearly in Fig. 8d–f. Therefore, it was concluded that the ceria incorporation greatly improved the NO x adsorption capacity of Cu-supported simple oxide catalysts, and the Ce x+ should play the main role in the nitrate adsorption on Cu/CeO2. According to the literature [37,47], the elevation of the NO x adsorption capacity should be attributed to the distortion of crystal structure caused by the generation of Ti–O–Ce mixed bonds, which may produce more adsorption centers for NO x . Moreover, due to the facilitation in the oxidation of NO into NO2 as mentioned previously, the more Lewis acid sites may also lead to the improvement of NO x adsorption. 3.3.2 Formation of adsorbed species during co-adsorption of reactants Fig. 9 shows the in situ FT-IR spectra of these catalysts during the reaction of NO+C3H6 +O2 in the temperature range of 150–350°C. Bridging nitrates (around 1608 and 1240cm−1), bidentate nitrates (around 1584cm−1) and monodentate nitrates (around 1280cm−1) were detected over various catalysts. The characteristic vibrations around 1587, 1547 and 1431cm−1 are assigned to acetate and the band around 1381cm−1 is attributed to formate [45,48]. For Cu/CeO2 sample, the band at 1406cm−1 is assigned to the bidentate carbonates or some COO− species [49], the band at 1451cm−1 may be attributed to the mixed band of acetate and nitrite [44], and the band at 1565cm−1 is assigned to the bidentate nitrates [45]. The chelate bidentate nitrates (Ce x+ =(O2)NO−) at 1522cm−1 also existed on the surface of Cu/CeO2. Furthermore, the bands at 2234 and 2201cm−1 are attributed to Cu-NCO and Ti-NCO species, respectively [4,50]. With the increase of reaction temperature, the persistent consumption of nitrates caused by the reaction with oxygenated hydrocarbons was observed. The nitrate species disappeared above 280°C over Cu/TiO2 and Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2, while some nitrates at 1240 and 1276cm−1 still existed over Cu/CeO2 even the temperature increased to 350°C, though the intensity of these bands was much lower. It should be noted that the intensity of Ce x+ =(O2)NO− at 1522cm−1 was enhanced with increasing the temperature. The intensity changes of the bands attributed to the adsorbed species with the temperature increase over the various catalysts can be seen more clearly in Fig. 9d–f. Among the tested catalysts, Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 sample exhibited the strongest adsorption capacity toward nitrates and oxygenated hydrocarbons, which acted as the intermediates and were beneficial to NO reduction. The nitrates adsorbed on the surface of Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 were more active to react with oxygenates in the SCR reaction than the other catalysts as they disappeared at a lowered temperature of about 260°C. Meanwhile, Cu/CeO2 exhibited weak adsorption capacity toward the intermediates, and the nitrates were stable and could not react with partial oxide hydrocarbons quickly. Hence, it was concluded that the high NO2 yield over Cu/CeO2 may be related to the low reactivity of nitrates toward oxygenates, especially the Ce x+ =(O2)NO−. At high temperature, nitrates may adsorb on the Ce x+ sites strongly, and the NO and/or nitrates were converted into NO2 by the Ce3+/Ce4+ redox couple. Also, the –NCO species with higher intensity were observed clearly on the surface of Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2, while the signal of –NCO species over Cu/TiO2 and Cu/CeO2 was much weaker. It has been reported that the HC-SCR reaction begins with the formation of nitrates and oxygenates, and the interaction between the two species produces the crucial intermediates –NCO species, then the –NCO species react with NO and O2 to form N2, which is called “reduction mechanism” [51–53]. Based on the “reduction mechanism”, the easier formation as well as the higher reactivity of nitrates, and the high concentration of –NCO species may result in the highest N2 yield over Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 catalyst. The key role of incorporated ceria was to promote the formation and activation of the nitrates, oxygenated hydrocarbons and –NCO species. 4 Conclusions A series of Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2 catalysts have been successfully prepared using the urea precipitation impregnation method. These catalysts have been shown to possess high activity for low-temperature C3H6-SCR of NO. The Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 sample exhibited the highest SCR activity with the maximum N2 yield and NO x conversion of 50.3% and 66.2% at 240°C, respectively. More NO2 was produced over the Ce-containing samples, and the maximum NO conversion to NO2 of 65.3% was obtained over Cu/CeO2 sample at 350°C. The catalyst characterization results confirmed that the incorporation of ceria into the TiO2 lattice caused the beneficial changes to the properties of the catalysts. The generation of Ti–O–Ce mixed bonds induced more Lewis acid sites, which subsequently played the beneficial role for the dispersion of ceria and copper oxides. Furthermore, the ceria introduction could increase the concentration of adsorbed oxygen and Cu2+, resulting in more adsorption centers, and thus acceleration of the NO oxidation as well as C3H6 activation. The appropriate addition of ceria conspicuously promoted the formation and reactivity of adsorbed nitrate, oxygenated hydrocarbons and key intermediates –NCO species. These features led to the superior activity of the Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 catalyst. In addition, the increase of Lewis acid sites and adsorbed oxygen with high mobility caused by ceria-doping also promoted the oxidative capacity of catalysts and therefore the NO2 yield over Ce-containing samples was significantly elevated. coredata.dc:description: A series of Cu-supported Ti–Ce mixed oxide catalysts (Cu/Ti1−x Ce x O2), with x =0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, 1.0, were evaluated for selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO with C3H6 under lean-burn conditions, and the promotional effect of ceria additive was investigated systematically. Among the tested catalysts, Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 exhibited excellent low-temperature activity, which achieved a maximum N2 yield of 50.3% and NO x conversion of 66.2% at 240°C. The generation of Ti–O–Ce mixed bond raised the quantity of Lewis acid sites and therefore improved the distribution of the copper oxide species on the catalyst surface. The high SCR activity of the Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 was mainly attributed to the abundant Lewis acid sites and the high ratio of adsorbed oxygen on the catalyst surface, which provided more adsorption centers for NO and promoted the NO oxidation in the SCR reaction. Furthermore, the high concentration of Cu2+ was beneficial to NO adsorption. Combined with the in situ FT-IR results, it was suggested that the synergistic effect of ceria and copper promoted the formation and reactivity of nitrates, oxygenated hydrocarbons, and key intermediates isocyanate (–NCO species), and consequently, Cu/Ti0.9Ce0.1O2 catalyst exhibited the excellent SCR performance.
coredata.dc:title: The selective catalytic reduction of NO with propene over Cu-supported Ti–Ce mixed oxide catalysts: Promotional effect of ceria
